title: Choto Shona Mosque
details:
Choto Shona Mosque, meaning 'Small Golden Mosque,' is an exquisite example of pre-Mughal Islamic architecture located in Chapai Nawabganj district of Rajshahi division. Built during the Sultanate period in the late 15th century, this mosque is renowned for its elegant proportions, intricate terracotta decorations, and the golden-hued patina that gives it its name. The mosque represents the architectural sophistication achieved during the Bengal Sultanate era.

To reach Choto Shona Mosque, travelers can take a bus from Dhaka to Chapai Nawabganj, which takes approximately 7-8 hours. From Nawabganj town, the mosque is located in the Shibganj upazila and can be reached by local transportation. The journey offers views of the region's mango orchards, for which Chapai Nawabganj is famous, and rural landscapes along the Mahananda River.

The mosque features a rectangular plan with three domes and is constructed primarily of brick with stone decorations. The exterior walls are adorned with beautiful terracotta ornamentation depicting floral motifs, geometric patterns, and calligraphic inscriptions from the Quran. The interior is equally impressive, with ornate mihrab (prayer niche) and intricate stonework that demonstrates the high level of craftsmanship of the period. The mosque originally had a golden coating on its domes, which has weathered over time but still gives the structure a distinctive warm glow, especially during sunrise and sunset.

Choto Shona Mosque is part of a larger complex of historical monuments in the area, including the nearby Darasbari Mosque and other Sultanate-era structures. The mosque remains an active place of worship while also serving as an important tourist attraction and archaeological site. Visitors can admire the architectural details, learn about Islamic art and architecture in medieval Bengal, and experience the spiritual atmosphere of this centuries-old sacred space.
seasons: Winter (November to February): The best time to visit with pleasant weather ideal for exploring the mosque and surrounding historical sites. Clear skies enhance photography opportunities.
Spring (March to April): Moderate temperatures with blooming mango orchards creating a beautiful setting around the mosque.
Autumn (October to November): Post-monsoon freshness with comfortable weather perfect for architectural appreciation.
cautions: Dress modestly as this is an active place of worship; women should cover their heads.
Remove shoes before entering the mosque premises.
Be respectful during prayer times and avoid disturbing worshippers.
Photography may be restricted inside the mosque; always ask permission.
Hire a local guide to learn about the architectural and historical significance.
Avoid visiting during Friday prayers when the mosque is most crowded.
Be careful not to touch or damage the delicate terracotta decorations.
Respect the sacred nature of the site and maintain appropriate behavior.
specials: Exquisite example of pre-Mughal Islamic architecture from the Bengal Sultanate period.
Beautiful terracotta ornamentation with floral motifs and Quranic calligraphy.
Distinctive golden-hued patina that gives the mosque its name.
Intricate stonework and ornate mihrab showcasing medieval craftsmanship.
Part of a larger complex of Sultanate-era monuments in the region.
Active place of worship maintaining centuries-old spiritual traditions.
Architectural features that influenced later Mughal mosque design in Bengal.
Peaceful setting surrounded by rural landscapes and mango orchards.
